entry.title: Armenia lifts visa requirements for Gulf states in bid to boost tourism: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS

media:group.media:title: Armenia lifts visa requirements for Gulf states in bid to boost tourism: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS
media:group.media:description:
üìç Armenia will lift visa requirements for citizens of Bahrain, Oman, and Saudi Arabia in a bid to boost tourism and attract more foreign investments. üìç Armenian officials confirmed they are in talks with Georgian counterparts over moves by Tbilisi to block Armenian brandy and wine exports to Russia. üìç Armenia‚Äôs gross domestic product expanded by 5.2% year-on-year in the first quarter, the country‚Äôs Statistical Committee said, largely in line with expert forecasts.

entry.title: New suspects arrested in 2020 Yerevan riot investigation

media:group.media:title: New suspects arrested in 2020 Yerevan riot investigation
media:group.media:description:
üìç Nine more people were arrested in connection with the mass unrest that erupted in Yerevan on November 10, 2020, following the announcement of the ceasefire agreement ending the Second Nagorno-Karabakh War. üìç Azerbaijan is attempting to revoke the UN consultative status of Christian Solidarity International (CSI), a human rights group advocating for the rights of Armenians from Nagorno-Karabakh. üìç The Armenian government approved a controversial new bill yesterday allowing young men to complete their mandatory military service in significantly shorter periods - if they pay a substantial fee. üìç France, Russia delayed in opening Syunik consulates: https://www.civilnet.am/en/news/952309/france-russia-delayed-in-opening-syunik-consulates/

entry.title: Rubio: U.S. Aims to Prevent Azerbaijani Invasion of Armenia

media:group.media:title: Rubio: U.S. Aims to Prevent Azerbaijani Invasion of Armenia
media:group.media:description:
üìç Secretary of State Marco Rubio told Congress the U.S. is working to prevent an Azerbaijani invasion of Armenia, amid bipartisan calls to enforce military aid restrictions and secure the release of prisoners held by Baku. üìç Most Armenians do not feel represented by any political force, according to the last year‚Äôs Caucasus Barometer survey. üìç The Armenian Genocide: From Recognition to Restitution- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nKcFcjSpN58

entry.title: From the Abraham Accords to India: Armenia‚Äôs Headlines Explained

media:group.media:title: From the Abraham Accords to India: Armenia‚Äôs Headlines Explained
media:group.media:description:
In this episode of the CivilNet podcast, political analyst Eric Hacopian covers some of the major developments in Armenia this week. He addresses speculation around Yerevan‚Äôs potential inclusion in the U.S.-brokered Abraham Accords and explores how the Trump administration may use the platform to reshape the South Caucasus. Hacopian also examines renewed efforts by Russia to reassert influence in Armenia, the political scuffles positioning former president Robert Kocharyan and his son Levon as the face of the opposition, and how rising tensions between India and Pakistan could have unexpected effects on Armenia.

entry.title: Russian foreign minister arrives in Armenia, says countries remain allies

media:group.media:title: Russian foreign minister arrives in Armenia, says countries remain allies
media:group.media:description:
üìç A cross-party committee of 19 Swiss parliamentarians will launch an initiative next week to support the return of displaced Armenians to Nagorno-Karabakh. This move is opposed by the country‚Äôs foreign ministry that believes the event would put Switzerland‚Äôs relations with Azerbaijan in danger. üìç Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov voiced Moscow‚Äôs support for Armenia‚Äôs sovereignty and its efforts to normalize relations with Azerbaijan during an official visit to Yerevan. üìç The legacy of Operation Nemesis: https://youtu.be/FQU1-ayMQlE?si=7_2BoGeNxM4qEWFS

entry.title: The Armenian Genocide: From Recognition to Restitution

media:group.media:title: The Armenian Genocide: From Recognition to Restitution
media:group.media:description:
Dr. Taner Ak√ßam, a renowned Turkish historian and the inaugural director of the Armenian Genocide Research Program of the Promise Armenian Institute at UCLA, joins CivilNet to discuss the need to shift from genocide recognition to restitution in the fight for justice. Following the formal recognition of the Armenian Genocide by the U.S., Ak√ßam argues that the next phase must focus on reparations - particularly the return of looted Armenian cultural artifacts held in American museums. Drawing on the model of Jewish restitution efforts, he outlines how legal avenues can be used to pursue accountability, even when state denial persists.
For more with Professor Ak√ßam from his 2025 visit to Armenia, watch: https://youtu.be/HQpiP5dPp08
